column4: kern.log prints on (almost) every line two timestamps. What do they refer to?
can you give an example of two timestamps?  usually 1 time stamp,  like Dec 1 20:30:20 in my logs
mom
mom is your example?
Dec 9 05:45:03 MD97600 kernel: [65786.900000] ACPI: PCI interrupt for device 0000:00:1f.2 disabled
thats 1 timestamp, Dec 9 05:45:03 = Dec 9 5:45 A.M
No there are two. The other one is [65786.900000].
like I said, 1 time stamp the other numbers refer probably to a specific location, #linux-kernel. Your "mom"comment I don't care for,thanks
In one line there are two time-stamps. Full stop. Have you ever analyzed dmesg?  --  Why do you mention '#linux-kernel'?
[16.094052] is not a time stamp, its common sense why i referred you to #linux-kernel for a kernel.log question
What is  [16.094052] then, if it is no time-stamp?
the output of dmesg does not contain any timestamps what so ever
Common sense has led many people in false directions. I have checked the activity in #linux-kernel. It appears to me that you have not.
Can you prove your statement.
prove what? that dmesg does not contain time stamps?
yes.
do you want people to help you or would you rather question there answers?
Please prove your statement that dmesg does not contain timestamps.
prove it to you? It simply does not contain timestamps
Tell me what the information content of  [16.094052] is.
kern.log does , dmesg does not include them in the output
